execution preconfirmations can only generally be useful to a subset of transactions where such a guarantee would be useful

Inclusion preconfirmations have no such limitation. The limitation is the cost of providing such a proof of execution for the preconfirmation itself. Such that the benefit must outweigh the compute cost of providing  that execution proof
there is an important distinction: execution preconfirmstions vs inclusion preconfirmstions

Dydx didn't use tokens to become dominant, the tokens came well after it was. Spark is an even stranger mention being an illegal (Aave's words) copypasta subsidized by Maker.

What I was thinking.  Users is very apropos term in crypto. They'll use you in the sense they'll stick around as long you incentivize them.  The second the apy drops or idea of getting airdrop is taken away they'll be gone.

That's one. Another is the very naive and innocent idea that those people will ever be users, at least in any significant numbers. 

But the worst one is the idea of "utility within the platform...constant demand". Every single product had that same idea, even some memecoins did. Reality is going to slap you so hard in the face when your chat is filled with "team, no users?? wat do to get users, I holding since tge and down a lot!"

Seed is difficult to raise regardless, it's high risk and most people who don't know you aren't willing to take that risk. If you want a seed round, reach out to friends and family or bootstrap your product. 

However, you should also sit back and ask yourself "do i REALLY need a token?" rather than trying to justify raising funds by trying to hamfist "utility" into it after the fact in a hope that random speculating user is actually going to use your product. 

And you're in for a world of hurt because you are inviting people who have no interest in anything you're doing beyond their entitlement to your efforts to give them a 100x moonshot.

If you're doing a serious product, bootstrap it and raise privately/friends and family. If you don't actually need a token, don't do a token. If the time comes where you might actually need a token, then cross that bridge when you get there. But in the earliest stages like this, it just seems — imo — completely unnecessary.

Look, if you're serious about it, this post is absolutely essential reading: https://posthog.com/founders/product-market-fit-game

But keep the following in mind:

1. There are maybe 30k unique users in crypto. Unless you have a product idea which is specifically well suited (e.g. 10x better or 10x cheaper than existing solutions to a problem you think they have) for that small niche, think WELL outside this bubble.
2. Most of these users in crypto function on bribes and short term gains. Neither retains users for any period of time.
3. There aren't more than 10 teams in crypto in total since the whole thing started that lasted more than 3 years. They all go bust because of 1), and because of programmed-in down-only token prices.
4. VCs in crypto are almost exclusively net negative, extractive, and zero-value-add. Exceptions exist (Signum, Sanctor...) but by and large they are vampiric and will look to you to help them dump on the 30k people.

My point is... whatever problem you think you're solving, do some user interviews first to make sure you really identified a high value problem to solve, otherwise you will become a solution looking for a problem.

You have three parts:
- read data from the internet
- do computations on your machine, spot market opportunities
- send data to the internet

Private keys authorized to spend money are only necessary for the 3rd part when you sign your request/tx.

The three parts are really independent in the sense that they tackle fairly different problems; the math guy doesn't need to know about how the software for key management works.

If you have the money to hire, you also have the time to learn.

Public AIs won't help you building useful trading algorithms, but you should use them to learn the basics of software development.

If you really wanna hire, hire  someone to teach you how computers stores and handle data as well as the basic cryptography and machine learning.

While some traders will say the above is not necessary, I think understand how computers work is a must.

That’s tricky because outside of pure blockchain in a world of classic apps it is either anonymity or security. You can’t have both.

To put it simply, imagine:
1. someone has stolen your phone authorization data 
2. and did something malicious, 
3. you have reported it 
4. and a police filled a criminal case, 
5. a police officer inquired from an exposed 2fa provider your account last activities, 
6. while following his official protocol, 
7. and 2fa provider is obligated to fulfill the request,
8. so the police will be able to track down the criminal.

Of course it’s a very simplified explanation. But.

If Bob wants to buy X eth at max price of $1505; Alice wants to buy Y ETH at max price of $1503 and market price is $1502 the options are:

(A) MEVbot sandwiches both of them to their max prices $1505 and $1503 but both tx execute.

(B) Encrypted mempool guarantees inclusion & ordering, without execution it puts Alice before Bob. Alice gets it at $1503 (price impact), Bob gets his at $1504 (his price impact). 

(C) Encrypted mempool guarantees inclusion and ordering, but without execution puts Bob before Alice. Bob gets his at $1503 but raises the price above Alice's max, causing her included & ordered tx to fail.

Obviously Alice prefers (B).
 Bob would prefer (C).
The benefit of (A) is they both get their tx executed successfully, but a MEVbot extracts both from of them.

There is no free lunch.
